name: Gulab Jamun
history: Gulab Jamun, a classic Indian sweet, is believed to have originated from a Persian dish. It became popular in the Indian subcontinent during the Mughal era.
description: Gulab Jamun is a delectable dessert made from milk solids, kneaded into a dough, shaped into balls, and deep-fried until golden brown. These balls are then soaked in a fragrant sugar syrup flavored with cardamom and rose water.

instructions.title: Make the Dough
instructions.description: In a mixing bowl, combine milk powder, all-purpose flour, and baking powder. Add melted ghee or butter and mix. Gradually add warm milk to form a soft dough.

instructions.title: Shape the Jamuns
instructions.description: Divide the dough into small balls, ensuring there are no cracks on the surface.

instructions.title: Prepare the Syrup
instructions.description: In a saucepan, dissolve sugar in water and bring to a boil. Add cardamom pods and simmer until the syrup thickens slightly. Stir in rose water.

instructions.title: Fry the Jamuns
instructions.description: Heat oil in a frying pan. Deep-fry the jamuns on low heat until they are dark golden brown. Remove and drain excess oil.

instructions.title: Soak in Syrup
instructions.description: While still warm, immerse the fried jamuns in the syrup. Let them soak for at least 2 hours before serving.

tips: Ensure the jamuns are smooth without cracks to prevent breaking while frying.
The syrup should be warm, not hot, when adding the fried jamuns.
variations: Kala Jamun: Add some cocoa powder to the dough for a darker color and rich taste.
Stuffed Jamun: Fill the dough balls with a mixture of nuts and saffron before frying.

storage.shelfLife: Can be stored in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.
storage.instructions: Keep in syrup in an airtight container.

reheatingInstructions: Serve at room temperature or slightly warmed.
presentationTips: Serve in a decorative bowl, garnished with silver leaf or chopped nuts.
Accompany with a scoop of vanilla ice cream for a decadent dessert.
